title: Ed Ruscha’s ‘Hurting the Word Radio #2’ Could Fetch $30M-$40M
text:
Text size

Ed Ruscha ’s Hurting the Word Radio #2, 1964—among the first announced highlights of Christie’s fall post-war and contemporary art sales—will be hitting the auction block for the first time in November with an estimate between $30 million and $40 million.

This early example of Ruscha’s pop text paintings could beat the artist’s current auction record of $30.4 million, including fees, for Smash, 1963. That record, achieved in November 2014 at Christie’s in New York, doubled a low estimate of $15 million, which in itself was considered high for a Ruscha work.

At the time, his auction record was shy of $7 million for Burning Gas Station, 1965-66, achieved at a Christie’s auction in New York in 2007.

“Everybody loved Smash,” says Ana Maria Celis, Christie’s head of evening sale, post-war and contemporary art. “It’s an iconic word, it had great scale, and it was from the ’60s, which made it really special.”

The exciting aspect of Radio, Celis says, is “we get to tell the story again, when we didn’t think we’d be able to tell the story again.”

Hurting the Word Radio #2 is being sold from the collection of Los Angeles journalist, artistic muse, and collector Joan Quinn and her late husband, Jack, an attorney who died at age 84 in 2017. The couple, who were friends and collectors of many Southern California artists beginning in the 1960s, were married for 55 years.

Ruscha, 81, is an American pop artist known for his playful typography, sharp use of color, and California landscapes. Both Radio and Smash were painted not long after Andy Warhol exhibited his Campbell Soup Cans at Ferus Gallery in Los Angeles in 1962, putting them in the center of contemporary pop art movement.

They are considered special, too, Celis says, because many of Ruscha’s text paintings are largely in museum collections.

There’s also evidence the market is primed for works by Ruscha. On Friday, Christie’s sold 35 works by the artist in the collection of architect Fred Clarke and his wife, Laura, for a total $7.5 million. A gunpowder on paper work, Wavy Robot, sold for $1.2 million, double its high estimate.

The provenance of Hurting the Word Radio #2 is top-notch, as the Quinns bought the painting directly from the artist in the early 1970s. According to Christie’s, Joan Quinn was a muse for Ruscha, as well as a string of other artists, including Robert Mapplethorpe, Jean-Michel Basquiat, David Hockney, and Andy Warhol.

Among several journalistic endeavors in the arts, Quinn was the West Coast editor for Warhol’s Interview magazine from 1978 to 1989.

Christie’s describes Hurting the Word Radio #2 as an “iconic example of Ed Ruscha’s c-clamp paintings,” in which the artist uses realistic images of c-clamps to distort the “R” and “O” in the word RADIO, laid out in large, sunny yellow capital letters on an azure blue background. Ruscha created only seven “c-clamp” works, all in 1964, and only four are of the same scale. Radio is smaller than Smash (71.7 inches by 67 inches) at 59 inches by 55 inches.

“The word in a way has this nostalgia attached to it—America and the ’60s,” Celis says. “The words he uses are modern and electric and car driven, and the word Radio has a wider connotation for so many more people.”
description: Christie’s to sell the pop artist’s 1960s text painting from the collection of Joan and Jack Quinn
